context: <b12_0>The Rhine<b12_0/> emerges from <b13_0>Lake Constance<b13_0/>, flows generally <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><a5_0><a5_1><a5_2>westward<a5_2/><a5_1/><a5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>, as the Hochrhein, passes the Rhine Falls, and is joined by its major tributary, the <a1_0><a1_2><a6_2><b10_0>river <a1_1><a6_0><a6_1>Aare<b10_0/><a6_2/><a6_1/><a6_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>. The Aare more than doubles the Rhine's water discharge, to an average of nearly <a2_0><a2_1><a7_0><a7_1><b11_0>1,000 m3/s<a7_1/><a2_1/> (35,000 cu ft/s)<b11_0/><a2_0/>,<a7_0/> and provides more than a fifth of the discharge at the Dutch border. The Aare also contains the waters from the 4,274 m (14,022 ft) <a3_1><a8_1><b14_0>summit of <a3_0><a3_2><a8_0><a8_2>Finsteraarhorn<b14_0/><a8_2/><a8_1/><a8_0/><a3_1/><a3_0/>, t<a3_2/>he highest point of the Rhine basin. The Rhine roughly forms the <a9_0><a9_1><a9_2>German<a9_2/><a9_0/>-Swiss border<a9_1/> from Lake Constance with the exceptions of the canton of Schaffhausen and parts of the cantons of Zürich and Basel-Stadt, until it turns north at the so-called Rhine knee at <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2>Basel<a4_1/><a4_0/>, leaving Switzerland<a4_2/>.
